sentences: Terri Lynn Clark (née Sauson; August 5, 1968) is a Canadian country music singer who has had success in both Canada and the United States.
section: N/A

sentences: Signed to Mercury Records in 1995, she released her self-titled debut that year.
section: N/A

sentences: Both it and its two follow-ups, 1996's Just the Same and 1998's How I Feel, were certified platinum in both countries, and produced several Top Ten country hits.
section: N/A

sentences: Her fourth album, 2000's Fearless, though certified gold in Canada, was not as successful in the U.S., producing no Top 10 hits.
section: N/A

sentences: Pain to Kill from 2003 restored her chart momentum in the U.S. with "I Just Wanna Be Mad" and "I Wanna Do It All", while a 2004 greatest hits album produced the Number One "Girls Lie Too".
section: N/A

sentences: A non-album single, "The World Needs a Drink", and the 2005 album Life Goes On were her last releases for Mercury before she signed to BNA Records in 2007.
section: N/A

sentences: There, she released the singles "Dirty Girl" and "In My Next Life".
section: N/A

sentences: Although the latter went to Number One in Canada, she has not released an album for BNA.
section: N/A

sentences: Clark's albums have accounted for more than twenty singles, including six Number Ones.
section: N/A

sentences: "If I Were You", "Poor Poor Pitiful Me", "Emotional Girl" and "In My Next Life" all topped the country charts in Canada (the former three were also U.S. Top Ten singles), "Girls Lie Too" reached number one only in the U.S., and "You're Easy on the Eyes" was number one in both countries.

== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Early life =
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===
== Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Clark was born Terri Lynn Sauson on August 5, 1968, in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Her family eventually settled in Medicine Hat, Alberta, where she was raised.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: She is the second of four children: she has a younger brother, Peter, an older sister, Kim, and younger sister, Tina.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Clark's grandparents, Ray and Betty Gauthier, were both noted Canadian country musicians, having opened for artists such as George Jones and Johnny Cash.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Clark's mother, Linda, had belonged to the Canadian folk scene.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Her parents divorced when she was young and her mother remarried, with Terri taking on her stepfather's last name.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: By high school, Clark had grown to love country music and worked at a local Chinese restaurant to save money to move to Nashville, Tennessee.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: After graduating from Crescent Heights High School in 1987, she moved to Nashville where she got her start playing at Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, a honky-tonk bar across the alley from Nashville's iconic Ryman Auditorium.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: At that time, country music executives were largely uninterested in traditional country, but record producer and singer Keith Stegall gave Clark advice and encouragement to not give up.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: In 1994, Stegall became an executive at PolyGram/Mercury Records in Nashville and promptly signed Clark to a record deal.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===
== Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: In 1995, Clark issued her first single, "Better Things to Do."
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: The song managed to reach the top five in both the United States and Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: Her debut album, Terri Clark, followed shortly after.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: Clark had a hand in writing or co-writing 11 of the album's 12 tracks.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: Terri Clark also featured the singles "When Boy Meets Girl," "If I Were You," and "Suddenly Single."
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: "If I Were You" became Clark's first No. 1 in Canada in June 1996.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: The album was certified Gold by the RIAA in the United States on April 5, 1996, and Platinum on July 29, 1997.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: In 1996, Clark's second studio album, Just the Same, was issued following the album's first single, "Poor Poor Pitiful Me," a cover of the 1976 Warren Zevon song.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: The song and its second single, "Emotional Girl," reached number one in Canada with both songs reaching the top ten in the United States.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: During late 1996, Clark was awarded Single of the Year for "Better Things to Do" and Album of the Year for Terri Clark by the Canadian Country Music Association.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: By 1997 she would also be awarded the Fans' Choice Award, an award she would win six more times between 2001 and 2007, and Female Artist of the Year, and award she would also claim in 2004 and 2005.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: In March 1998, Clark visited Calgary, Alberta, Canada to film her first television special, Terri Clark: Coming Home, which premiered March 27 on CBC in Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===

sentences: During the special Clark was visited by Canadian country singers Paul Brandt and George Fox.
section: == Biography == | === 1995–1997: Terri Clark and Just the Same ===
== Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless =
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===
== Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: Clark's third studio album, How I Feel, was issued in May 1998.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: The album's lead single
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: , "Now That I Found You," reached the top five in both the United States and Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: It was the album's second single, "You're Easy on the Eyes," that gave Clark's first American No. 1, the song also reached No. 1 in Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: "You're Easy on the Eyes" became a minor Top 40 hit, peaking at No. 40 on the Billboard Hot 100 in the United States.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: To promote the new album, Clark was added as the opening act for Reba McEntire and Brooks & Dunn 1998 tour.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: Fearless, Clark's fourth studio album, was issued in September 2000.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: During the album's production, Clark started writing more personal songs with a new team of co-writers and hired a new producer to deliver a set of songs with a more acoustic feel than that of her previous work.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: The album's first single, "A Little Gasoline", was a late addition to the album because Mercury executives felt Clark needed to balance her new material with something that had a more familiar feel to it.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: The song reached the top ten in Canada, however, only reaching No. 13 in the United States.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: On May 2, 2001, Clark was pulled over by police for speeding in Nashville.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: The officer, who pulled Clark over, had suspected that she had consumed alcohol and asked her to do sobriety test, after which Clark refused and was charged with a DUI and implied consent.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: Clark later apologized for the incident through a statement that was issued to press by her publicist.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===

sentences: In August, Clark pleaded guilty to a charge of reckless driving and was fined $350 plus court costs, placed on six months' supervised probation and ordered to take an alcohol education course.
section: == Biography == | === 1998–2001: How I Feel and Fearless ===
== Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===
== Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 =
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===
== Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: After a management change in December 2001, Clark began work on her fifth studio album, Pain to Kill.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The album was issued in January 2003, followed after the release of the album's first single, "I Just Wanna Be Mad".
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The song, written by Kelley Lovelace and Lee Thomas Miller, was initially intended to be recorded by Sara Evans, who passed on it.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: When released as a single the song became Clark's highest-charting single in the United States since 1998's "You're Easy on the Eyes" and is to date Clark's highest appearance on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100, peaking at No. 27.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The album marked the first time Clark had worked with producer Byron Gallimore, who produced the first half of the album.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The other half was produced by Clark's longtime producer Keith Stegall, who was brought in when Gallimore became unavailable.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: In early 2004, Clark was approached by Playboy magazine to pose—clothed—for the cover of the magazine's upcoming May issue.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Clark, who came in second place behind fellow Canadian country singer Shania Twain in a poll in the previous year, turned down the offer saying "I think of all the young girls who come to my shows, I think of those faces, I think of my mother, and I worry about the signal [sex] sends to them[…] If I’m sexy enough for Playboy to want me with my clothes on, then I hope the message can be that sexy is about what’s between your ears, in your heart and your smile.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: "On May 15, 2004, during a performance of the Grand Ole Opry, Clark was surprised by Steve Wariner and her mother Linda with an invitation to join the Grand Ole Opry.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Clark was officially inducted on June 12, 2004, and is currently the only female Canadian member of the Grand Ole Opry.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Shortly after her induction, Clark's first greatest hits album, Greatest Hits 1994–2004, was issued.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The album's only single, "Girls Lie Too", became Clark's first number one in the United States since 1998's "You're Easy on the Eyes".
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: While the song did not reach number one in Canada, it was the named number one country song of 2004 in Canada by Radio & Records.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: A non-album single, "The World Needs a Drink" (which was co-written by a then-unknown Eric Church), was released in late 2004, but was not included on any of Clark's studio albums.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===
== Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===
== Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home =
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===
== Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: In 2005, Clark's sixth studio album, Life Goes On, was issued in November.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The album's first single, "She Didn't Have Time", only managed to reach No. 25 in the United States and No. 15 in Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: None of the album's other singles charted in the United States and Clark parted ways with Mercury Records in March 2006.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: In June 2006, Clark signed with BNA Records, a division of Sony BMG label group, now known as Sony Music Entertainment.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark's first single for the label, "Dirty Girl", was issued in early 2007.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The song was then followed by "In My Next Life", which was to be the title track to her debut BNA release.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark, along with Canadian country band Emerson Drive, opened for Big & Rich in Canada, hoping to promote the new album.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: My Next Life was delayed several times and remained unreleased leaving Clark to part ways with BNA in November 2008, so she could concentrate more on her career in Canada and possibly launch her own record label.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark released a live album, Terri Clark Live: Road Rage, via Clark's own BareTrack Records label in July 2009 through digital retailers.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark's seventh studio album, The Long Way Home, was released shortly after to all retailers in Canada and digital retailers in the United States on September 1, 2009, via BareTrack/Capitol Nashville/EMI Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The album was released to non-digital retailers in the United States on October 20, 2009.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The first single issued from the album was "Gypsy Boots", a song previously recorded for Clark's unreleased My Next Life album.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The single was released to country radio in Canada on June 22, 2009, and country radio in the United States on July 20.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: The video for "Gypsy Boots," directed by Margaret Malandruccolo, was released in Canada on August 6, 2009, and is available for online viewing at Clark's site.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: "If You Want Fire", "A Million Ways To Run" and "You Tell Me"  have been issued as follow up singles in Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===
== Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===
== Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: Roots and Wings and Classic
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===
== Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: Clark released her eighth studio album, Roots and Wings, on July 26, 2011.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: It includes "Smile", a song she wrote for her mom after her death due to a long battle with cancer.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: The album's lead off single, "Northern Girl," was released on April 18, 2011.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: "We're Here for a Good Time," "The One," and "Wrecking Ball," were all also released as singles from the album.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: Clark's ninth studio album, Classic, was released on November 13, 2012, in Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: The album includes classic country standards such as "Love Is a Rose", which was issued as the album's lead single, and features duets with Reba McEntire, Jann Arden, Dierks Bentley, Tanya Tucker and Dean Brody.
section: == Biography == | === 2011–2013: Roots and Wings and Classic ===

sentences: 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar =
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===
== Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: Clark's tenth studio album, Some Songs, was produced by Michael Knox.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: It was released on September 2, 2014, and includes ten songs.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: The album was funded through PledgeMusic and was distributed by Clark's own BareTrack Records and Universal Music Canada.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: The album's first single, "Some Songs", shipped to Canadian country radio on May 26.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: Clark previously co-hosted America's Morning Show on Nash FM with Blair Garner and Chuck Wicks.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: As of the April 9/10 weekend in 2016, Terri became the new hostess of the Saturday night classic country program Country Gold, replacing Randy Owen.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: In 2018, Clark was inducted into the Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: Clark's eleventh studio album, Raising the Bar, was released on September 14, 2018.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===

sentences: Clark's first holiday album, "It's Christmas...Cheers!" will be released on September 25, 2020, by Mercury Nashville.
section: == Biography == | === 2014–present: Some Songs and Raising the Bar ===
